bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Howard A. Kelly, December 10, 1922

div1.p: Carter discusses his connection to the work of Reed's Yellow Fever Commission. Carter maintains that Reed informed him that the direction taken by the Yellow Fever Commission, in Cuba, was inspired by his early work with yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Howard A. Kelly, December 10, 1922
div1.opener:
Mis #(4
Kelly,
Please return to
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
/LC
Washington, D. C.,
December 10, 1922.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1406 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Md.
Dear Doctor Kelly:
div1.p:
Your note of December 5th. received and I very grateful for the
expressions of appreciation therein expressed.

Few discoveries are ma de entirely by one man and I have been
content with the belief that my work was of assistance to Reed in
his demonstration of the mechanism of the conveyance of yellow
fever--indeed, as he wrote me, determined the direction of his ex-
perimentation.

I am sorry to say that of the articles written prior to 1901
I have only a single reprint--that “on the Spread of Yellow Fever
in Houses. Extrinsic Incubation.” These articles, however, are
in the Library of the Surgeon General of the Army here, as a per-
manent loan, although one is in MSS as I had no reprint.

I wonder is it taking a liberty--it is done simply from
fear you might make a possible error--to advise you that I am posi-
tive, from the statements of both Reed and Carroll (July 4, 1900)
at Quemados, that Dr. Sternberg not only did not contemplate any
investigation of yellow fever as a host-borne disease, but such
suggestions as he have them were incompatible with this method of
conveyance, stressing to them conveyance by fomites as a fact univer-
sally admitted and advising that they investigate the intestinal
intestinal
2
flora--especially of the stomach and duodenum.

I say this simply because your letter includes Sternberg in
the same connection with Reed and Gorgas. A careful; painstaking;
consciencious man was Sternberg, widely read in yellow fever lit-
erature, but lacking the imagination and insight that led Finlay
to the truth.
Once more thanking you for your very kind letter, I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, (Signed) H. R. Carter. Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
